query: What is the main contribution regarding asymptotic theory for constrained M-estimation?
What are the primary assumptions regarding the loss function and convex constraint sets?
How do the asymptotic distributions of M-estimators depend on the loss and constraint boundary?
What practical applications are discussed for constrained M-estimation with convex loss?
What mathematical tools from convex analysis are utilized to develop the asymptotic theory?
How does this work differ from prior asymptotic theories assuming smoothness and local domination?
What are the findings regarding the consistency of convex M-estimators under constraints?
How is the asymptotic theory extended to U-estimators with convex loss functions?
Can you describe a simple illustrative example of constrained M-estimation with metric projection?
What foundational theoretical aspects regarding empirical minimizer existence are discussed?
